thread.title: Millwall request more tickets for FA Cup quarter-final after Tottenham's initial offer of 2,800 seats
thread.title_full: Millwall request more tickets for FA Cup quarter-final after Tottenham's initial offer of 2,800 seats

author: tom collomosse
title: Millwall request more tickets for FA Cup quarter-final after Tottenham's initial offer of 2,800 seats

organizations.name: white hart lane tottenham hotspur fc

text:
Thursday 23 February 2017 07:59 GMT Click to followES Sport Derby Day | Tottenham will face Millwall in what is expected to be the club's final FA Cup appearance at White Hart Lane Tottenham Hotspur FC via Getty Images 
Millwall have requested more tickets for their FA Cup quarter-final clash at Tottenham after the Premier League club made an initial offer of 2,800. 
The number offered to Lions is significantly lower than the maximum allocation for away fans for FA Cup matches, which equates to about 4,700 – 15 per cent of what Spurs’ stadium holds. To allow work to proceed on Tottenham’s new 61,000-seat ground, White Hart Lane is currently operating at a reduced capacity of about 31,500. 
Tottenham held talks with the FA, broadcasters and their local Safety Advisory Group , which comprises representatives from police, fire brigade, council and the club itself. After these talks, they settled on a figure of 2,800 – but Millwall chief executive Steve Kavanagh has asked for about 4,000 for the last-eight tie, to be shown live on BBC One on March 12. 
Kavanagh argues that the higher number will reduce the risk of Millwall supporters trying to buy tickets in the home sections of the ground. FA confirm early Sunday kick-off for Spurs vs Millwall 
He said: “The initial number is just over 2,800. But we’re aware that Wycombe received 4,000 [in the fourth round] and Aston Villa were offered 4,000 [in the third round]. We think we should get the same allocation as those clubs.” 
“To me, it wouldn’t be safe to not offer that number. It’s easier to control and manage fans within the confine of the grounds rather than having Millwall fans trying to buy tickets in the Tottenham end. We want Millwall fans in an area together where they can enjoy the game in a safe environment. 
“They’ve given us their initial thoughts based on what their Safety Advisory Group believe the allocation should be. We have challenged that and requested more. 
“I want to get as many Millwall fans in there as possible, as it is a huge game for the club. It’s only right that our fans are given a fair chance to get a ticket.” In Pictures | Tottenham train ahead of Gent clash | 22/02/2017 In Pictures | Tottenham train ahead of Gent clash | 22/02/2017 1/15
